Question_1.Context: The study explored the application of green ultrasound-assisted technology for the extraction of oil from rainbow trout intestines. Purification methodologies were incorporated using adsorbents to enhance the quality of the extracted oil.
Question_1.Question: What was the extraction condition for maximum oil recovery?
Question_1.Source: The oil extraction efficiency was 43.5% at 5 min of ultrasonication time, and the highest extraction yield of 46.5% was obtained at 30 min. The oil recoveries decreased to 44.4% and 42.1% when the duration of the ultrasonic extraction was increased to 45 and 60 min, respectively.

Question_2.Context: The study focused on the impact of the water-to-sample ratio on oil recovery during ultrasound-assisted extraction.
Question_2.Question: How did the oil recovery change with the addition of water during ultrasound-assisted extraction?
Question_2.Source: Oil recovery from the rainbow trout intestines decreased with the addition of water during UAE. When no water was added, the sample was hydrolyzed and achieved a 47.9% oil recovery. The yield decreased to 44.3% when the water-to-sample ratio (v/w) was 1:1 (v/w) and 42.3% at the ratio of 3:2.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the impact of temperature on the ultrasound-assisted extraction process for oil recovery.
Question_3.Question: How did the oil recovery change with increasing temperature?
Question_3.Source: Initially, the oil yield increased from 47.6% to 50 °C to 54.7% at 60 °C, but the extraction efficiency decreased when the temperature was increased to 70 and 80 °C, resulting in oil recoveries of 53.3% and 48.5%, respectively.

Question_4.Context: The study evaluated the impact of NaCl levels on oil recovery during ultrasound-assisted extraction.
Question_4.Question: What was the effect of increasing the amount of added NaCl on oil recovery?
Question_4.Source: Adding 1 g of NaCl to the samples during extraction increased the oil recovery to 53.8%. The oil recovery decreased when the amount of added NaCl exceeded 1 g, resulting in yields of 49.7% and 47.3% when 2 and 3 g of NaCl were added, respectively.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the impact of adsorbent materials on the peroxide value of the extracted oil during the purification process.
Question_5.Question: Which adsorbent material was the most effective in reducing the peroxide value of the extracted oil?
Question_5.C: Mixture of silica gel and aluminum oxide
Question_5.Source: SG was found to be the most effective adsorbent among the materials tested, lowering the POV by up to 58.6%, followed by a mixture of SG and Al2O3, with a 54.0% decrease in the POV, and Al2O3 was the least effective, lowering the POV by 50.6% compared to the pre-purified oil.

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the impact of adsorption time on the peroxide value of the extracted oil during the purification process using silica gel.
Question_6.Question: How did the peroxide value change with increasing adsorption time using silica gel?
Question_6.Source: After extending the adsorption time to 30 min, the POV significantly decreased to 23.3 meqO2/kg, with a removal rate of 29.2% compared to the oil after 10 min of adsorption. Extending the adsorption time to 60 min led to a measured POV of 10 meqO2/kg, with a removal efficiency of 69.1%.

Question_7.Context: The study focused on the impact of adding antioxidants during the extraction process on the peroxide value of the extracted oil.
Question_7.Question: How did the peroxide value change with the addition of antioxidants during the extraction process?
Question_7.Source: Compared to the extracted oil without added antioxidants, the inclusion of antioxidants tannic acid, gallic acid, and Aronia during the extraction process decreased the POV significantly.

Question_8.Context: The study analyzed the impact of adding antioxidants during the extraction process on the concentrations of fatty acids in the extracted oil.
Question_8.Question: What was the effect of adding antioxidants during the extraction process on the concentrations of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) in the extracted oil?
Question_8.Source: The concentrations of PUFAs in the extracted oil increased from 101 ± 8 mg/g without added antioxidants to 131 ± 5 mg/g with tannic acid, 132 ± 6 mg/g with gallic acid, and 130 ± 3 mg/g with the addition of Aronia during the early stages of extraction.

Question_9.Context: The study examined the impact of adding antioxidants during the extraction process on the ratio of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids in the extracted oil.
Question_9.Question: What was the omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acid ratio in the oils added with tannic acid, gallic acid, and Aronia powder during the extraction process?
Question_9.Source: The ratios of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids in oils added with tannic acid, gallic acid, Aronia powder, and without antioxidants were 0.596, 0.599, 0.594, and 0.634, respectively.

Question_10.Context: The study evaluated the impact of antioxidants on the removal of organic compounds in the extracted oil.
Question_10.Question: What was the effect of adding antioxidants during the extraction process on the removal of organic compounds in the extracted oil?
Question_10.Source: The analytical results indicated a significant decrease in the fractions of the organic compounds after the addition of antioxidants during extraction. Specifically, the removal rates were 67.1% with tannic acid, 50.3% with gallic acid, and 43.7% with the addition of Aronia powder.
